1.text: The proverbs of Solomon the son of David, the king of Israel:

2.text: For knowing wisdom and instruction; / For discerning words of understanding;

3.text: For receiving instruction in wise conduct, / Righteousness, justice, and equity;

4.text: For giving prudence to the simple, / Knowledge and discretion to the young man;

5.text: That the wise man may hear and increase in learning, / And he who has understanding may acquire sound counsel;

6.text: For understanding proverb and figure, / The words of the wise and their difficult sayings.

7.text: The fear of Jehovah is the beginning of knowledge; / Fools despise wisdom and instruction.

8.text: Hear, my son, the instruction of your father, / And do not reject the teaching of your mother;

9.text: For they will be a wreath of grace for your head / And ornaments for your neck.

10.text: My son, if sinners entice you, / Do not consent.

11.text: If they say, Come with us; let us lie in wait for blood; / Let us ambush the innocent without cause;

12.text: Let us swallow them alive like Sheol, / And whole, like those who go down into the pit.

13.text: We will find all manner of precious goods; / We will fill our houses with booty;

14.text: Throw in your lot with us; / We will all have one purse --

15.text: My son, do not walk with them on this way; / Keep your foot from their path.

16.text: For their feet run toward evil, / And they hasten to shed blood.

17.text: For in vain is the net spread / In the eyes of any bird;

18.text: Yet they lie in wait for their own blood; / They ambush their own lives!

19.text: Such are the ways of everyone greedy for gain; / It takes away the life of its owners.

20.text: Wisdom cries out in the street; / She utters her voice in the open squares.

21.text: At the head of the tumultuous street she cries; / At the entrance of the gates in the city she utters her sayings:

22.text: How long, O simple ones, will you love simpleness, / And will scoffers delight themselves in scoffing, / And will fools hate knowledge?

23.text: Turn yourselves at my reproof -- / Immediately I will pour out my spirit on you; / I will make my words known to you.

24.text: Because I called and you refused; / I stretched out my hand and no one heeded,

25.text: And you neglected all my counsel / And would have none of my reproof;

26.text: I also will laugh at your calamity; / I will mock when what you dread comes,

27.text: When what you dread comes like a storm, / And your calamity comes like a whirlwind, / When distress and anguish come upon you.

28.text: Then they will call on me, but I will not answer; / They will seek me diligently, but they will not find me.

29.text: Because they hated knowledge / And did not choose the fear of Jehovah,

30.text: And would have none of my counsel / And despised all my reproof;

31.text: They shall eat of the fruit of their own way / And be filled with their own devices.

32.text: For the turning away of the simple will kill them, / And the prosperity of the foolish will cause them to perish;

33.text: But he who listens to me will dwell securely / And will live at ease, without the dread of evil.

1.text: My son, if you receive my words / And treasure up my commandments within you,

2.text: Making your ear attentive to wisdom / And inclining your heart to understanding;

3.text: Indeed, if you cry out for discernment / And lift up your voice for understanding;

4.text: If you seek her like silver / And search for her like hidden treasures,

5.text: Then you will understand the fear of Jehovah / And find the knowledge of God.

6.text: For Jehovah gives wisdom; / From His mouth come knowledge and understanding;

7.text: He stores up sound wisdom for the upright; / He is a shield to those who walk in integrity,

8.text: Guarding the paths of justice / And keeping the way of His faithful ones.

9.text: Then you will understand righteousness and justice / And equity, indeed, every good path.

10.text: For wisdom will enter your heart, / And knowledge will be pleasant to your soul;

11.text: Discretion will watch over you; / Understanding will keep you:

12.text: To deliver you from the way of evil, / From the man who speaks perverse things,

13.text: From those who forsake the paths of uprightness / To walk in the ways of darkness,

14.text: Who rejoice in doing evil / And delight in the perverseness of evil,

15.text: Whose paths are crooked, / And who are devious in their ways;

16.text: To deliver you from the strange woman, / From the adulteress who flatters with her words,

17.text: Who forsakes the companion of her youth / And forgets the covenant of her God;

18.text: For her house sinks down to death, / And her paths lead to the dead;

19.text: None who go to her ever return, / Nor do they attain to the paths of life;

20.text: That you may walk in the way of good men / And keep the paths of the righteous;

21.text: For the upright will dwell in the land, / And the perfect will remain in it;

22.text: But the wicked will be cut off from the land, / And the treacherous will be uprooted from it.

1.text: My son, do not forget my instruction, / But let your heart keep my commandments;

2.text: For length of days and years of life / And peace will they add to you.

3.text: Do not let lovingkindness and truth forsake you: / Bind them around your neck; / Write them upon the tablet of your heart.

4.text: Thus you will find favor and a reputation for fine understanding / In the sight of God and man.

5.text: Trust in Jehovah with all your heart, / And do not rely on your own understanding;

6.text: In all your ways acknowledge Him, / And He will make your paths straight.

7.text: Do not be wise in your own eyes; / Fear Jehovah, and depart from evil.

8.text: It will be healing to your body / And refreshment to your bones.

9.text: Honor Jehovah with your substance / And with the firstfruits of all your produce;

10.text: Then your barns will be filled with plenty, / And your vats will burst open with new wine.

11.text: My son, do not despise the chastening of Jehovah, / Nor be weary of His discipline;

12.text: For whom Jehovah loves He disciplines, / Even as a father, the son in whom he delights.

13.text: Blessed is the man who finds wisdom, / And the man who gains understanding.

14.text: For her profit is better than the profit of silver, / And her income is better than gold.

15.text: She is more precious than corals, / And nothing you desire compares with her.

16.text: Length of days is in her right hand; / In her left hand are riches and honor.

17.text: Her ways are ways of pleasantness, / And all her paths are peace.

18.text: She is a tree of life to those who lay hold of her, / And happy are those who hold her fast.

19.text: Jehovah by wisdom founded the earth; / He established the heavens by understanding;

20.text: By His knowledge the depths were broken open / And the skies drop down the dew.

21.text: My son, do not let these depart from your sight: / Keep sound wisdom and discretion;

22.text: And they will be life for your soul / And a graceful ornament for your neck.

23.text: Then you will walk on your way securely, / And your foot will not stumble.

24.text: When you lie down, you will not be afraid; / But you will lie down, and your sleep will be sweet.

25.text: Do not be afraid of sudden fear, / Nor of the destruction of the wicked when it comes;

26.text: For Jehovah will be your confidence, / And He will keep your foot from being caught.

27.text: Do not withhold good from those to whom it is due, / When it is in the power of your hand to do so.

28.text: Do not say to your neighbor, Go, and come back; / And tomorrow I will give it-- when you have it with you.

29.text: Do not devise harm against your neighbor, / While he lives securely beside you.

30.text: Do not strive with a man without cause, / If he has done you no harm.

31.text: Do not envy a man of violence, / And do not choose any of his ways;

32.text: For the perverse man is an abomination to Jehovah, / But His intimate counsel is with the upright.

33.text: The curse of Jehovah is in the house of the wicked man, / But He blesses the dwelling place of the righteous.

34.text: To scorners He is scornful, / But to the humble He gives grace.

35.text: The wise will inherit honor, / But fools increase their own disgrace.

1.text: Hear, my sons, the instruction of a father, / And be attentive, that you may gain understanding;

2.text: For I give you good teaching; / Do not forsake my instruction.

3.text: For I was a son to my father, / Tender and the only beloved in the sight of my mother.

4.text: And he taught me and said to me, / Let your heart hold fast to my words; / Keep my commandments and live;

5.text: Get wisdom; get understanding; / Do not forget nor turn away from the words of my mouth.

6.text: Do not forsake her, and she will keep you; / Love her, and she will guard you.

7.text: The beginning of wisdom is this: / Get wisdom; and in all your getting, get understanding.

8.text: Prize her highly, and she will exalt you; / She will honor you if you embrace her.

9.text: She will give a garland of grace for your head; / A crown of beauty will she bestow on you.

10.text: Hear, my son, and receive my words, / And the years of your life will be many.

11.text: I have taught you in the way of wisdom; / I have led you in the paths of uprightness.

12.text: When you walk, your steps will not be hindered; / And when you run, you will not stumble.

13.text: Take hold of instruction; do not let go; / Guard her, for she is your life.

14.text: Do not enter the path of the wicked, / And do not walk in the way of the evil.

15.text: Avoid it; do not pass by it; / Turn away from it and pass on by.

16.text: For they cannot sleep unless they do evil; / And they are robbed of their sleep unless they cause someone to stumble.

17.text: For they eat the bread of wickedness / And drink the wine of violence.

18.text: But the path of the righteous is like the light of dawn, / Which shines brighter and brighter until the full day.

19.text: The way of the wicked is like deep darkness; / They do not know what they stumble over.

20.text: My son, be attentive to my words; / Incline your ear to my sayings.

21.text: Do not let them depart from your sight; / Keep them in the midst of your heart.

22.text: For they are life to those who find them, / And healing to all their flesh.

23.text: Keep your heart with all vigilance, / For from it are the issues of life.

24.text: Put away from you crooked speech, / And put perverse talk far from you.

25.text: Let your eyes look directly ahead, / And let your gaze be straight in front of you.

26.text: Make straight the path of your feet, / And all your ways will be established.

27.text: Do not turn to the right or to the left; / Turn your foot away from evil.

1.text: My son, be attentive to my wisdom; / Incline your ear to my understanding,

2.text: That you may keep discretion, / And your lips may guard knowledge.

3.text: For the lips of a strange woman drip honey, / And her mouth is smoother than oil;

4.text: But in the end she is bitter as wormwood, / Sharp as a two-edged sword.

5.text: Her feet go down to death; / Her steps hold fast to Sheol.

6.text: She does not make straight the path of life: / Her ways wander, and she does not know it.

7.text: And now, my sons, listen to me, / And do not depart from the words of my mouth.

8.text: Keep your way far from her, / And do not go near the door of her house;

9.text: Lest you give your honor to others, / And your years to the cruel;

10.text: Lest strangers be filled with your wealth, / And your labors go to the house of a foreigner,

11.text: And you mourn at your end, / When your flesh and your body are consumed,

12.text: And you say, How I have hated instruction, / And my heart has despised reproof!

13.text: And I have not listened to the voice of my teachers / Nor inclined my ear to my instructors;

14.text: I was almost into every evil / In the midst of the congregation and assembly.

15.text: Drink waters out of your own cistern, / And running water out of your own well.

16.text: Should your springs be shed forth, / Like streams of water in the streets?

17.text: Let them be yours alone, / And not for strangers with you.

18.text: Let your fountain be blessed, / And rejoice in the wife of your youth,

19.text: A lovely hind and a graceful doe. / Let her breasts satisfy you at all times. / May you be ravished with her love always.

20.text: For why should you be ravished, my son, with a strange woman / And embrace the bosom of an adulteress?

21.text: For the ways of a man are before the eyes of Jehovah, / And He ponders all his paths.

22.text: The wicked man is taken by his own iniquities, / And he is held fast by the cords of his own sin.

23.text: He will die for lack of instruction, / And in the greatness of his folly he will go astray.

1.text: My son, if you have become a surety for your neighbor, / If you have given your hands as a pledge for a stranger,

2.text: You are snared by the words of your mouth; / You are caught by the words of your mouth.

3.text: Do this now, my son, and deliver yourself, / Since you have come into the hand of your neighbor: / Go, humble yourself, and plead with your neighbor.

4.text: Do not give sleep to your eyes, / Nor slumber to your eyelids.

5.text: Deliver yourself like a gazelle from the hunter's hand / And like a bird from the fowler's hand.

6.text: Go to the ant, you sluggard; / Consider its ways, and be wise,

7.text: Which, having no chief, / Officer, or ruler,

8.text: Prepares its food in summer / And gathers its sustenance in the harvest.

9.text: How long, sluggard, will you lie there? / When will you arise from your sleep?

10.text: A little sleep, a little slumber, / A little folding of the hands to rest,

11.text: And your poverty will come upon you like a robber, / And your want, like an armed man.

12.text: A worthless man, a wicked man, / Goes around with a perverse mouth,

13.text: Winking with his eyes, signaling with his feet, / Pointing with his fingers;

14.text: With perverseness in his heart, he is devising evil continually; / He injects discord.

15.text: Therefore his calamity will come suddenly; / In a moment he will be broken, and there will be no remedy.

16.text: There are six things that Jehovah hates; / Indeed, seven that are an abomination to His soul:

17.text: Haughty eyes, a lying tongue, / And hands that shed innocent blood,

18.text: A heart that devises wicked schemes, / Feet that hurry to run to evil,

19.text: A false witness who utters lies, / And one who injects discord among brothers.

20.text: My son, keep the commandment of your father, / And do not reject the teaching of your mother;

21.text: Bind them continually on your heart; / Tie them around your neck.

22.text: When you walk about, it will guide you, / When you lie down, it will watch over you; / And when you awake, it will talk with you.

23.text: For the commandment is a lamp, and the teaching a light, / And the reproofs of instruction are the way of life,

24.text: To keep you from the evil woman, / From the smooth tongue of the adulteress.

25.text: Do not desire her beauty in your heart, / Nor let her catch you with her eyelids;

26.text: For the price of a harlot is a loaf of bread, / But the wife of another man hunts for the precious soul.

27.text: Can a man take fire in his bosom / And his clothes not be burned?

28.text: Can a man walk on hot coals / And his feet not be scorched?

29.text: So it is with him who goes in to his neighbor's wife; / No one who touches her will be unpunished.

30.text: The thief is not despised if he steals / To satisfy himself when he is hungry;

31.text: But if he is found out, he shall restore sevenfold; / He must give over all the substance of his house.

32.text: He who commits adultery with a woman lacks sense; / He who does it destroys his own soul.

33.text: He will find wounds and dishonor, / And his reproach will not be wiped away.

34.text: For jealousy is the rage of a man, / And he will not spare in the day of vengeance.

35.text: He will not regard any ransom, / Nor will he be content if you give him great gifts.

1.text: My son, keep my words, / And treasure up my commandments within you.

2.text: Keep my commandments, and live; / And my teaching, like the pupil of your eye.

3.text: Bind them on your fingers; / Write them on the tablet of your heart.

4.text: Say to wisdom, You are my sister, / And call understanding your close friend,

5.text: That they may keep you from the strange woman, / From the adulteress who flatters with her words.

6.text: For at the window of my house / I looked out through my lattice,

7.text: And I saw among the simple ones, / I discerned among the youths, / A young man lacking sense,

8.text: Passing along the street near her corner; / And he takes the way to her house,

9.text: In the twilight, in the evening of the day, / In the deep of night and darkness.

10.text: And there comes a woman to meet him, / Dressed as a harlot and cunning of heart.

11.text: She is rowdy and defiant; / Her feet do not stay at home --

12.text: Now in the street, now in the squares, / And at every corner she lies in wait.

13.text: And she grabs him and kisses him; / And with an impudent face she says to him,

14.text: I had to make offerings; / Today I have paid my vows.

15.text: Therefore I have come out to meet you, / To earnestly seek your presence; and I have found you.

16.text: I have decked my couch with coverings, / Colored spreads of the linen of Egypt;

17.text: I have sprinkled my bed with myrrh, / Aloes, and cinnamon.

18.text: Come, let us drink our fill of love until the morning; / Let us delight ourselves with love.

19.text: For my husband is not at home; / He has gone on a long journey.

20.text: He has taken the money bag with him; / He will come home at the full moon.

21.text: With her great persuasiveness she beguiles him; / With her smooth talk she compels him.

22.text: He goes after her immediately, / As an ox goes to the slaughter, / Or as someone in fetters, to the correction of the fool,

23.text: Until an arrow pierces through his liver. / As a bird hastens to the snare, / So he does not know that this will cost him his life.

24.text: And now, my sons, listen to me, / And pay attention to the words of my mouth.

25.text: Do not let your heart turn aside to her ways; / Do not stray into her paths.

26.text: For many are those whom she has brought down wounded, / And numerous are all who have been slain by her.

27.text: Her house is the way to Sheol, / Going down to the chambers of death.

1.text: Does not wisdom call, / And understanding lift up her voice?

2.text: On the top of the heights, by the way, / Where the paths meet, she takes her stand;

3.text: Beside the gates, at the entry of the city, / At the entrance of the doors, she cries aloud:

4.text: To you, O men, I call; / And my voice is to the sons of men.

5.text: O simple ones, understand prudence; / And, O fools, be of an understanding heart.

6.text: Hear, for I will speak noble things; / And the opening of my lips will yield right things.

7.text: For my mouth will utter truth, / And wickedness is an abomination to my lips.

8.text: All the words of my mouth are in righteousness; / There is nothing twisted or crooked in them.

9.text: They are all straight to him who understands, / And right to those who find knowledge.

10.text: Receive my instruction, and not silver; / And knowledge rather than choice gold.

11.text: For wisdom is better than corals, / And nothing that you desire compares with her.

12.text: I, wisdom, dwell with prudence, / And I find knowledge and discretion.

13.text: The fear of Jehovah is to hate evil; / Pride and arrogance and the evil way / And the perverse mouth, I hate.

14.text: Counsel is mine and sound wisdom; / I am understanding; I have might.

15.text: By me kings reign, / And rulers decree justice.

16.text: By me princes rule, / And nobles -- all who judge righteously.

17.text: I love those who love me, / And those who seek me diligently will find me.

18.text: Riches and honor are with me, / Enduring wealth and righteousness.

19.text: My fruit is better than gold, even fine gold; / And my yield than choice silver.

20.text: I walk in the way of righteousness, / In the midst of the paths of justice,

21.text: That I may cause those who love me to inherit substance / And that I may fill their treasuries.

22.text: Jehovah possessed me in the beginning of His way, / Before His works of old.

23.text: I was set up from eternity, / From the beginning, before the earth was.

24.text: When there were no depths, I was brought forth, / When there were no fountains abounding with water.

25.text: Before the mountains were settled, / Before the hills, I was brought forth;

26.text: When He had not yet made the earth and the fields, / Nor the first dust of the world.

27.text: When He established the heavens, I was there; / When He inscribed a circle upon the surface of the deep,

28.text: When He made firm the skies above, / When the fountains of the deep became strong,

29.text: When He set for the sea its boundary, / That the waters should not transgress His commandment, / When He marked out the foundations of the earth;

30.text: Then I was by Him, as a master workman; / And I was daily His delight, / Rejoicing always before Him,

31.text: Rejoicing in His habitable earth; / And my delight was in the sons of men.

32.text: Now therefore, my sons, listen to me; / For blessed are they who keep my ways.

33.text: Hear instruction, and be wise; / And do not neglect it.

34.text: Blessed is the man who listens to me, / Watching daily at my doors, / Waiting at my doorposts.

35.text: For whoever finds me finds life, / And will obtain favor from Jehovah.

36.text: But he who sins against me wrongs his own soul; / All who hate me love death.

1.text: Wisdom has built her house; / She has hewn out her seven pillars;

2.text: She has slaughtered her beasts; / She has mingled her wine; / She has also set her table;

3.text: She has sent forth her maidens; / She calls from the highest places of the city:

4.text: Whoever is simple, let him turn in here; / As for him who lacks sense, she says to him,

5.text: Come, eat of my bread, / And drink of the wine which I have mingled.

6.text: Forsake foolishness, and live, / And walk in the way of understanding.

7.text: He who corrects a scorner gets dishonor for himself, / And he who reproves a wicked man blemishes himself.

8.text: Do not reprove a scorner, lest he hate you; / Reprove a wise man, and he will love you.

9.text: Impart something to a wise man, and he will become wiser still; / Teach a righteous man, and he will increase in learning.

10.text: The fear of Jehovah is the beginning of wisdom, / And the knowledge of the Holy One is understanding.

11.text: For by me your days will be multiplied, / And the years of your life will be increased.

12.text: If you are wise, you are wise for yourself; / And if you are scornful, you alone will bear it.

13.text: The woman Foolishness is rowdy; / She is simple and knows nothing.

14.text: And she sits at the door of her house, / On a seat in the heights of the city,

15.text: To call to those who pass by, / Who go straight on their ways:

16.text: Whoever is simple, let him turn in here; / And as for him who lacks sense, she says to him,

17.text: Stolen waters are sweet, / And bread gotten in secret is pleasant.

18.text: But he does not know that the dead are there, / That her guests are in the depths of Sheol.

1.text: The proverbs of Solomon. A wise son makes a father glad, / But a foolish son is a grief to his mother.

2.text: Treasures of wickedness profit nothing, / But righteousness delivers from death.

3.text: Jehovah will not allow the soul of the righteous man to go hungry, / But He thrusts away the desire of the wicked.

4.text: A slack hand causes poverty, / But the hand of the diligent makes rich.

5.text: He who gathers in summer is a prudent son, / But he who sleeps at harvest time is a son who brings shame.

6.text: Blessings are upon the head of the righteous man, / But the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.

7.text: The memory of the righteous man is blessed, / But the name of the wicked will rot.

8.text: The wise in heart will receive commandments, / But the foolish in speech will be cast down.

9.text: He who walks in integrity walks securely, / But he who perverts his ways will be known.

10.text: He who winks with the eye causes grief, / And the foolish in speech will be cast down.

11.text: The mouth of the righteous man is a fountain of life, / But the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.

12.text: Hatred stirs up strife, / But love covers all transgressions.

13.text: In the lips of one who has understanding wisdom is found, / But a rod is for the back of him who lacks sense.

14.text: Wise men treasure up knowledge, / But the mouth of a fool is imminent destruction.

15.text: The rich man's substance is his strong city; / The ruin of the poor is their poverty.

16.text: The wages of the righteous man lead to life; / The income of the wicked man, to sin.

17.text: He who heeds instruction is on the path of life, / But he who forsakes reproof goes astray.

18.text: He who conceals hatred has lying lips, / And he who utters slander is a fool.

19.text: When there are many words transgression does not cease, / But he who restrains his lips is prudent.

20.text: The tongue of the righteous man is like choice silver; / The heart of the wicked is worth little.

21.text: The lips of the righteous man feed many, / But fools die for lack of sense.

22.text: It is the blessing of Jehovah that makes rich, / And He adds no sorrow with it.

23.text: Carrying out a wicked scheme is like sport to a fool, / But so is wisdom to a man of understanding.

24.text: The fear of the wicked man will come upon him, / And the desire of the righteous will be granted.

25.text: When the whirlwind passes, the wicked man is no more; / But the righteous man is an everlasting foundation.

26.text: Like vinegar to the teeth and like smoke to the eyes, / So is the sluggard to those who send him.

27.text: The fear of Jehovah prolongs days, / But the years of the wicked will be shortened.

28.text: The hope of the righteous is joy, / But the expectation of the wicked will perish.

29.text: The way of Jehovah is a stronghold to the upright, / But it is ruin to the workers of iniquity.

30.text: The righteous man will never be moved, / But the wicked will not dwell in the land.

31.text: The mouth of the righteous man brings forth wisdom, / But the perverse tongue will be cut off.

32.text: The lips of the righteous man know what is acceptable, / But the mouth of the wicked is perverse.

1.text: A false balance is an abomination to Jehovah, / But a full weight is His delight.

2.text: When pride comes, then comes dishonor; / But wisdom is with the humble.

3.text: The integrity of the upright will guide them, / But the perverseness of the treacherous will destroy them.

4.text: Riches do not profit in the day of wrath, / But righteousness delivers from death.

5.text: The righteousness of the perfect man will make his way straight, / But the wicked man will fall by his own wickedness.

6.text: The righteousness of the upright will deliver them, / But the treacherous will be taken in their own craving.

7.text: When a wicked man dies, his expectation will perish; / And the hope of the strong perishes.

8.text: The righteous man is delivered out of trouble, / And the wicked man comes into it instead of him.

9.text: With his mouth the profane man destroys his neighbor, / But through knowledge the righteous will be delivered.

10.text: When it goes well with the righteous, the city exults; / And when the wicked perish, there is a ringing shout.

11.text: By the blessing of the upright the city is exalted, / But it is torn down by the mouth of the wicked.

12.text: He who despises his neighbor lacks sense, / But a man of understanding keeps silent.

13.text: He who goes about as a gossip reveals secrets, / But he who is of a faithful spirit conceals a matter.

14.text: Where no sound counsel is, the people fall; / But in the multitude of counselors there is safety.

15.text: He who is surety for a stranger will surely be troubled, / But he who hates giving pledges is secure.

16.text: A gracious woman lays hold of honor, / And violent men lay hold of riches.

17.text: The merciful man rewards his own soul, / But the cruel troubles his own flesh.

18.text: The wicked man earns deceitful wages, / But he who sows righteousness gets a true reward.

19.text: He who is steadfast in righteousness shall attain to life, / And he who pursues evil advances to his own death.

20.text: Those who are perverse in heart are an abomination to Jehovah, / But those who are perfect in their way are His delight.

21.text: Be assured: The evil man will not go unpunished; / But the seed of the righteous will be delivered.

22.text: Like a nose-ring of gold in a pig's snout, / So is a beautiful woman who is without discretion.

23.text: The desire of the righteous is only good, / But the expectation of the wicked is wrath.

24.text: There is one who scatters and increases yet more, / And there is one who withholds what is appropriate but ends up only in want.

25.text: The blessing soul will prosper, / And he who waters will also be watered himself.

26.text: As for him who withholds grain, the people will curse him; / But blessing will be upon the head of him who sells it.

27.text: He who diligently seeks good seeks favor; / But as for him who searches after evil, it will come to him.

28.text: He who trusts in his riches will fall, / But the righteous will flourish like the green leaf.

29.text: He who troubles his own house will inherit the wind, / And a fool will be servant to the wise in heart.

30.text: The fruit of the righteous man is a tree of life, / And he who is wise wins souls.

31.text: If the righteous man will be recompensed on the earth, / How much more the wicked man and the sinner!

1.text: Whoever loves correction loves knowledge, / But he who hates reproof is stupid.

2.text: A good man will obtain the favor of Jehovah, / But a man of wicked devices He will condemn.

3.text: A man will not be established by wickedness, / But the root of the righteous will not be moved.

4.text: A worthy woman is the crown of her husband, / But she who brings shame is like rottenness in his bones.

5.text: The thoughts of the righteous are just, / But the counsels of the wicked are deceitful.

6.text: The words of the wicked lie in wait for blood, / But the mouth of the upright will deliver them.

7.text: The wicked are overthrown and are no more, / But the house of the righteous will stand.

8.text: A man will be praised according to his prudence, / But he who is of a perverse heart will be despised.

9.text: Better is he who is lightly esteemed and has a servant, / Than he who honors himself and lacks bread.

10.text: A righteous man regards the life of his beast, / But the inward parts of the wicked are cruel.

11.text: He who tills his land will have plenty of bread, / But he who pursues worthless things lacks sense.

12.text: The wicked man desires the catch of evil men, / But the root of the righteous yields fruit.

13.text: In the transgression of the lips there is a snare for the evil man, / But the righteous man will come out of trouble.

14.text: A man will be satisfied with good by the fruit of his mouth, / And the result of man's deeds will be rendered to him.

15.text: The way of a fool is right in his own eyes, / But a wise man listens to counsel.

16.text: A fool's anger is known at once, / But a prudent man conceals shame.

17.text: He who utters truth tells forth righteousness; / But a false witness, deceit.

18.text: There is one who speaks rashly like the piercings of a sword, / But the tongue of the wise brings healing.

19.text: The lip of truth shall be established forever, / But a lying tongue is only for a moment.

20.text: Deceit is in the heart of those who devise evil, / But counselors of peace have joy.

21.text: No harm will happen to the righteous man, / But the wicked are filled with trouble.

22.text: Lying lips are an abomination to Jehovah, / But those who deal faithfully are His delight.

23.text: A prudent man conceals knowledge, / But the heart of fools proclaims folly.

24.text: The hand of the diligent will rule, / But the slothful will be under forced labor.

25.text: Anxiety in the heart of a man weighs it down, / But a good word brings it joy.

26.text: The righteous man is a guide to his neighbor, / But the way of the wicked leads them astray.

27.text: The slothful man does not roast his game, / But the precious substance of men is to the diligent.

28.text: In the way of righteousness is life, / And in its pathway there is no death.

1.text: A wise son hears his father's instruction, / But a scorner does not listen to rebuke.

2.text: A man will eat good from the fruit of his mouth, / But the desire of the treacherous is violence.

3.text: He who guards his mouth keeps his soul, / But he who opens wide his lips will have destruction.

4.text: The soul of the sluggard desires and has nothing, / But the soul of the diligent will be made fat.

5.text: A righteous man hates what is false, / But a wicked man is odious and is confounded.

6.text: Righteousness guards him who is blameless in the way, / But wickedness overthrows the sinner.

7.text: There is one who pretends to be rich yet has nothing; / There is one who pretends to be poor yet has great wealth.

8.text: The ransom of a man's life is his riches, / But the poor hears no threatening.

9.text: The light of the righteous rejoices, / But the lamp of the wicked goes out.

10.text: Through pride comes nothing but strife, / But wisdom is with those who receive counsel.

11.text: Wealth obtained by vanity will be diminished, / But he who gathers by labor increases it.

12.text: Hope deferred makes the heart sick, / But when what is desired comes, it is a tree of life.

13.text: Whoever despises the word brings destruction on himself, / But he who fears the commandment will be rewarded.

14.text: The teaching of the wise is a fountain of life, / That one may turn aside from the snares of death.

15.text: Good understanding gives favor, / But the way of the treacherous is hard.

16.text: Every prudent man works with knowledge, / But a fool displays his folly.

17.text: A wicked messenger falls into evil, / But a faithful envoy brings healing.

18.text: Poverty and shame will come to him who refuses correction, / But he who regards reproof will be honored.

19.text: A desire accomplished is sweet to the soul, / But it is an abomination to fools to depart from evil.

20.text: He who walks with wise men will be wise, / But the companion of fools will be troubled.

21.text: Evil pursues sinners, / But good recompenses the righteous.

22.text: A good man leaves an inheritance to his children's children, / But the wealth of the sinner is stored up for the righteous man.

23.text: The fallow ground of the poor yields much food, / But it is destroyed through injustice.

24.text: He who spares his rod hates his son, / But he who loves him chastens him early.

25.text: The righteous man eats to the satisfying of his soul, / But the belly of the wicked will lack.

1.text: The wise woman builds her house, / But the foolish one tears it down with her own hands.

2.text: He who walks in his uprightness fears Jehovah, / But he who is perverse in his ways despises Him.

3.text: In the mouth of a fool is a rod for his pride, / But the lips of the wise will preserve them.

4.text: Where no oxen are, the manger is clean, / But much increase comes by the strength of the ox.

5.text: A faithful witness will not lie, / But a false witness utters lies.

6.text: A scoffer seeks wisdom and finds none, / But knowledge comes easily to one who has understanding.

7.text: Go from the presence of a foolish man, / For you will not perceive in him the lips of knowledge.

8.text: The wisdom of the prudent man is to understand his way, / But the folly of fools is deceit.

9.text: A trespass offering mocks fools, / But among the upright there is good will.

10.text: The heart knows its own bitterness, / And a stranger does not share in its joy.

11.text: The house of the wicked will be destroyed, / But the tent of the upright will flourish.

12.text: There is a way which seems right to a man, / But the end of it is the ways of death.

13.text: Even in laughter the heart is sorrowful, / And the end of joy is grief.

14.text: The backslider in heart will be filled with his own ways, / And a good man will be satisfied from himself.

15.text: The simple man believes every word, / But the prudent man considers his steps.

16.text: A wise man fears and departs from evil, / But the fool is arrogant and is confident.

17.text: He who is quick to anger will deal foolishly, / And a man of wicked devices is hated.

18.text: The simple inherit folly, / But the prudent are crowned with knowledge.

19.text: The evil bow down before the good, / And the wicked, at the gates of the righteous man.

20.text: The poor man is hated even by his own neighbor, / But the rich man has many friends.

21.text: He who despises his neighbor sins, / But happy is he who is gracious to the poor.

22.text: Do not they who devise evil go astray? / But lovingkindness and truth are with those who devise good.

23.text: In all labor there is profit, / But mere talk leads only to poverty.

24.text: The crown of the wise is their riches, / But the folly of fools is only folly.

25.text: A truthful witness delivers souls, / But he who utters lies causes deceit.

26.text: In the fear of Jehovah is strong confidence, / And his children will have a place of refuge.

27.text: The fear of Jehovah is a fountain of life, / That one may turn aside from the snares of death.

28.text: In a multitude of people is the king's glory, / But in an absence of people is the ruin of the prince.

29.text: He who is slow to anger is of great understanding, / But he who has a hasty spirit exalts folly.

30.text: A tranquil heart is life to the flesh, / But envy is rottenness to the bones.

31.text: He who oppresses the poor reproaches his Maker, / But he who is gracious to the needy honors Him.

32.text: The wicked man is thrust down in his evildoing, / But the righteous man has a refuge when he dies.

33.text: Wisdom rests quietly in the heart of one who has understanding, / But in the inward part of fools it makes itself known.

34.text: Righteousness exalts a nation, / But sin is a reproach to any people.

35.text: The king's favor is toward a servant who acts prudently, / But his overflowing wrath will be toward him who causes shame.

1.text: A soft answer turns away anger, / But a grievous word stirs up anger.

2.text: The tongue of the wise utters knowledge well, / But the mouth of fools pours out folly.

3.text: The eyes of Jehovah are in every place, / Keeping watch on the evil and the good.

4.text: A soothing tongue is a tree of life, / But perverseness in it is a breaking of the spirit.

5.text: A fool despises his father's correction, / But he who regards reproof gets prudence.

6.text: In the house of the righteous man there is much treasure, / But in the income of the wicked there is trouble.

7.text: The lips of the wise disperse knowledge, / But the heart of fools does not do so.

8.text: The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination to Jehovah, / But the prayer of the upright is His delight.

9.text: The way of the wicked man is an abomination to Jehovah, / But He loves one who pursues righteousness.

10.text: There is grievous correction for one who forsakes the way, / And he who hates reproof will die.

11.text: Sheol and Abaddon lie open before Jehovah. / How much more the hearts of the children of men!

12.text: A scorner does not love him who reproves him; / He will not go to the wise.

13.text: A joyful heart makes a cheerful countenance, / But by sorrow of heart the spirit is broken.

14.text: The heart of one who has understanding seeks knowledge, / But the mouth of fools feeds on folly.

15.text: All the days of the afflicted are evil, / But he who is of a cheerful heart has a continual feast.

16.text: Better is a little with the fear of Jehovah / Than great treasure and turmoil with it.

17.text: Better is a dinner of vegetables where love is / Than a fattened ox and hatred with it.

18.text: A wrathful man stirs up contention, / But he who is slow to anger quiets strife.

19.text: The way of the sluggard is like a hedge of thorns, / But the path of the upright is paved.

20.text: A wise son makes a father glad, / But a foolish man despises his mother.

21.text: Folly is joy to him who lacks sense, / But a man of understanding makes straight his going.

22.text: Where there is no counsel, plans are frustrated; / But in the multitude of counselors they are established.

23.text: A man has joy in the apt answer of his mouth; / And a word in its season, how good it is!

24.text: To the wise man the way of life leads upward, / That he may depart from Sheol below.

25.text: Jehovah will tear down the house of the proud, / But He will establish the territory of the widow.

26.text: Evil plans are an abomination to Jehovah, / But pleasant words are pure.

27.text: He who is greedy for gain troubles his own house, / But he who hates bribes will live.

28.text: The heart of the righteous man ponders how to answer, / But the mouth of the wicked pours out evil things.

29.text: Jehovah is far from the wicked, / But He hears the prayer of the righteous.

30.text: The light of the eyes rejoices the heart, / And good news makes the bones fat.

31.text: The ear that listens to the reproof of life / Will lodge among the wise.

32.text: He who ignores instruction despises his own soul, / But he who listens to reproof acquires understanding.

33.text: The fear of Jehovah is the instruction of wisdom, / And humility goes before honor.

1.text: The plans of the heart belong to man, / But the answer of the tongue is from Jehovah.

2.text: All the ways of a man are clean in his own eyes, / But Jehovah weighs the spirits.

3.text: Commit your works to Jehovah, / And your purposes will be established.

4.text: Jehovah has made everything for its own purpose, / Yes, even the wicked for the day of evil.

5.text: Every one who is proud in heart is an abomination to Jehovah; / Be assured: He will not be unpunished.

6.text: By lovingkindness and truth iniquity is expiated, / And by the fear of Jehovah men depart from evil.

7.text: When a man's ways please Jehovah, / He causes even his enemies to be at peace with him.

8.text: Better is a little with righteousness, / Than great income with injustice.

9.text: A man's heart devises his way, / But Jehovah directs his steps.

10.text: A divine decision is on the lips of the king; / His mouth will not transgress in judgment.

11.text: A just balance and just scales are Jehovah's; / All the weights of the bag are His work.

12.text: It is an abomination to kings to commit wickedness, / For the throne is established by righteousness.

13.text: Righteous lips are the delight of kings, / And they love one who speaks right.

14.text: The wrath of a king is as messengers of death, / But a wise man will appease it.

15.text: In the light of the king's countenance is life, / And his favor is like a cloud of the latter rain.

16.text: How much better it is to acquire wisdom than gold, / And to acquire understanding is to be chosen above silver.

17.text: The highway of the upright is to depart from evil; / He who keeps his way preserves his soul.

18.text: Pride goes before destruction, / And a haughty spirit before a fall.

19.text: It is better to be of a lowly spirit with the poor, / Than to divide the spoil with the proud.

20.text: He who gives heed to the word will find good, / And blessed is he who trusts in Jehovah.

21.text: The wise in heart will be called discerning, / And the sweetness of speech increases persuasiveness.

22.text: Insight is a fountain of life to him who has it, / But the correction of fools is folly.

23.text: The heart of the wise man instructs his mouth / And adds persuasiveness to his lips.

24.text: Pleasant words are a honeycomb, / Sweet to the soul and healing to the bones.

25.text: There is a way which seems right to a man, / But the end of it is the ways of death.

26.text: The appetite of the laboring man labors for him; / For his mouth urges him on.

27.text: A worthless man digs up evil, / And on his lips there is a scorching fire.

28.text: A perverse man spreads strife, / And a whisperer separates close friends.

29.text: A man of violence entices his neighbor / And leads him in a way that is not good.

30.text: He who shuts his eyes does so to devise perverse things; / He who compresses his lips brings evil to pass.

31.text: The gray head is a crown of glory; / It will be found in the way of righteousness.

32.text: He who is slow to anger is better than the mighty; / And he who rules his spirit, than he who captures a city.

33.text: The lot is cast into the lap, / But everything it decides is from Jehovah.

1.text: Better is a dry morsel and quietness with it / Than a house full of feasting with strife.

2.text: A servant who deals wisely will rule over a son who causes shame, / And will share in the inheritance among brothers.

3.text: The refining pot is for silver and the furnace for gold, / But Jehovah tries the hearts.

4.text: An evildoer gives heed to wicked lips, / And a liar gives ear to a mischievous tongue.

5.text: Whoever mocks the poor reproaches his Maker; / He who rejoices at calamity will not go unpunished.

6.text: Grandchildren are the crown of old men, / And the glory of children is their fathers.

7.text: Excellent speech is not fitting for a fool; / Much less are lying lips for a noble man.

8.text: A bribe is like a precious stone in the eyes of its possessor: / Wherever he turns, he prospers.

9.text: He who covers a transgression seeks love, / But he who repeats a matter separates close friends.

10.text: A rebuke strikes deeper into him who has understanding / Than a hundred stripes into a fool.

11.text: An evil man seeks only rebellion; / Therefore a cruel messenger will be sent against him.

12.text: Let a bear robbed of her cubs meet a man / Rather than a fool in his folly.

13.text: Whoever rewards evil for good, / Evil will not depart from his house.

14.text: The beginning of contention is like letting out water; / Therefore abandon strife before it breaks out.

15.text: He who justifies the wicked man, and he who condemns the righteous man, / Both of them are an abomination to Jehovah.

16.text: Why is there a price in the hand of a fool to buy wisdom, / When he has no sense?

17.text: A friend loves at all times, / And a brother is born for adversity.

18.text: A man lacking sense gives his hand as a pledge / And becomes surety in the presence of his neighbor.

19.text: He who loves transgression loves strife; / He who raises high his entrance seeks destruction.

20.text: He who has a crooked heart finds no good, / And he who has a perverse tongue falls into evil.

21.text: He who begets a fool does so to his sorrow, / And the father of a fool has no joy.

22.text: A joyful heart is good medicine, / But a broken spirit dries up the bones.

23.text: A wicked man receives a bribe from the bosom, / To pervert the ways of justice.

24.text: Wisdom is before the face of him who has understanding, / But the eyes of a fool are on the ends of the earth.

25.text: A foolish son is a grief to his father, / And bitterness to her who bore him.

26.text: To also punish the righteous man is not good, / Nor to strike nobles for their uprightness.

27.text: He who restrains his words has knowledge, / And he who is cool in spirit is one who has understanding.

28.text: Even a fool, when he keeps silent, is counted wise; / When he shuts his lips, he is counted prudent.

1.text: He who separates himself seeks his own desire / And rages against all sound wisdom.

2.text: A fool has no delight in understanding, / But only that his heart may reveal itself.

3.text: When the wicked man comes, contempt also comes; / And with dishonor comes reproach.

4.text: The words of a man's mouth are deep waters, / A gushing stream, a fountain of wisdom.

5.text: To respect the person of the wicked man is not good, / Nor to turn aside the righteous man in judgment.

6.text: A fool's lips bring strife, / And his mouth invites blows.

7.text: A fool's mouth is his ruin, / And his lips are the snare of his soul.

8.text: The words of a whisperer are like dainty morsels, / And they go down into the innermost parts of one's being.

9.text: He also who is slack in his work / Is brother to him who is a destroyer.

10.text: The name of Jehovah is a strong tower; / The righteous man runs into it and is safe.

11.text: The rich man's substance is his strong city / And like a high wall in his own imagination.

12.text: Before destruction the heart of man is haughty, / But humility goes before honor.

13.text: As for him who gives an answer before he hears, / It is folly and shame.

14.text: The spirit of a man can sustain his sickness, / But a broken spirit who can bear?

15.text: The heart of one who has understanding acquires knowledge, / And the ear of the wise seeks knowledge.

16.text: A man's gift makes room for him / And brings him before great men.

17.text: The first to plead his case seems just, / Until his neighbor comes and cross-examines him.

18.text: The lot causes contentions to cease / And decides between the mighty.

19.text: A brother offended is harder to be gained than a strong city, / And contentions are like the bars of a castle.

20.text: With the fruit of his mouth a man's stomach will be satisfied; / With the produce of his lips he will be satisfied.

21.text: Death and life are in the power of the tongue, / And those who love it will eat its fruit.

22.text: Whoever finds a wife finds a good thing, / And obtains favor from Jehovah.

23.text: The poor man utters supplications, / But the rich man answers roughly.

24.text: A man of many friends comes to destruction, / But there is a true friend that sticks closer than a brother.

1.text: Better is a poor man who walks in his integrity / Than he who is perverse in his lips and is a fool.

2.text: Also it is not good for a person to be without knowledge, / And he who makes haste with his feet sins.

3.text: The foolishness of a man subverts his way, / And his heart is indignant toward Jehovah.

4.text: Wealth adds many friends, / But the poor man is separated from his friend.

5.text: A false witness will not go unpunished, / And he who utters lies will not escape.

6.text: Many will entreat the favor of the generous man, / And every man is a friend to one who gives gifts.

7.text: All the brothers of the poor man hate him; / How much more do his friends go far from him! / He pursues them with words, but they are not there.

8.text: He who acquires sense loves his own soul; / He who keeps understanding will find good.

9.text: A false witness will not go unpunished, / And he who utters lies will perish.

10.text: Delicate living is not fitting for a fool; / Much less for a servant to rule over princes.

11.text: The discretion of a man makes him slow to anger, / And it is his glory to overlook a transgression.

12.text: The king's wrath is like the roaring of a lion, / But his favor is like dew upon the grass.

13.text: A foolish son is the ruin of his father, / And the contentions of a wife are a continual dripping.

14.text: House and wealth are an inheritance from fathers, / But a prudent wife is from Jehovah.

15.text: Slothfulness casts into a deep sleep, / And the idle soul will suffer hunger.

16.text: He who keeps the commandment keeps his soul; / He who is careless of his ways will die.

17.text: He who has pity upon a poor man lends to Jehovah, / And He will repay him for his good deed.

18.text: Discipline your son, for there is hope; / But do not set your heart on destroying him.

19.text: A man of great wrath will bear the penalty; / For if you deliver him, you will only have to do it again.

20.text: Listen to counsel, and receive instruction, / That you may be wise at the end of your days.

21.text: There are many devices in a man's heart, / But it is the counsel of Jehovah that will stand.

22.text: What is desirable in a man is his kindness, / And a poor man is better than a liar.

23.text: The fear of Jehovah leads to life, / And he who has it will lodge in contentment; / He will not be visited with evil.

24.text: The sluggard buries his hand in the dish, / And will not even bring it back to his mouth.

25.text: Strike a scorner, and the simple will learn prudence; / And reprove one who has understanding, and he will understand knowledge.

26.text: He who does violence to his father and chases away his mother / Is a son that causes shame and brings reproach.

27.text: Cease listening, my son, to instruction, / And you will stray from the words of knowledge.

28.text: A worthless witness mocks justice, / And the mouth of the wicked swallows up iniquity.

29.text: Judgments are prepared for scorners, / And blows for the back of fools.

1.text: Wine is a mocker, strong drink a brawler; / And whoever errs by it does not become wise.

2.text: The terror of a king is like the roaring of a lion; / He who provokes him to anger sins against his own life.

3.text: It is an honor for a man to keep away from strife, / But every fool rushes headlong into it.

4.text: The sluggard will not plow because of winter; / Therefore he will beg in harvest and have nothing.

5.text: Counsel in the heart of man is like deep water, / But a man of understanding will draw it out.

6.text: Many a man will proclaim his own kindness, / But who can find a faithful man?

7.text: A righteous man who walks in his integrity, / Blessed are his children after him.

8.text: A king who sits on the throne of judgment / Scatters away all evil with his eyes.

9.text: Who can say, I have made my heart clean; / I am pure from my sin?

10.text: Differing weights and differing measures, / Both of them are an abomination to Jehovah.

11.text: Even a child makes himself known by his deeds, / Whether his work is pure and whether it is upright.

12.text: The hearing ear and the seeing eye -- / Jehovah has made both of them.

13.text: Do not love sleep, or else you will come to poverty; / Open your eyes, and be satisfied with bread.

14.text: It is bad, it is bad, says the buyer; / But when he has gone away, then he boasts in his purchase.

15.text: There is gold and an abundance of corals, / But the lips of knowledge are a precious jewel.

16.text: Take his garment when he becomes surety for a stranger, / And hold the pledge when he becomes surety for foreigners.

17.text: The bread of falsehood is sweet to a man, / But afterward his mouth will be filled with gravel.

18.text: Every plan is established by counsel, / And by sound counsel make war.

19.text: He who goes about as a gossip reveals secrets; / Therefore do not associate with one who opens his lips wide.

20.text: Whoever curses his father or his mother, / His lamp will go out in deep darkness.

21.text: An inheritance gained hurriedly at the beginning / Will not be blessed in the end.

22.text: Do not say, I will recompense evil; / Wait for Jehovah, and He will save you.

23.text: Differing weights are an abomination to Jehovah, / And false scales are not good.

24.text: A man's steps are ordered by Jehovah; / How then can man understand his own way?

25.text: It is a snare to a man to rashly say, It is holy, / And after making the vows to begin to consider.

26.text: A wise king winnows the wicked / And drives the threshing wheel over them.

27.text: The spirit of man is the lamp of Jehovah, / Searching all the innermost parts of the inner being.

28.text: Lovingkindness and truth preserve the king, / And his throne is upheld by kindness.

29.text: The glory of young men is their strength, / And the honor of old men is gray hair.

30.text: Stripes that wound purge away evil, / And strokes reach the innermost parts of the inner being.

1.text: The king's heart is like streams of water in the hand of Jehovah; / He turns it wherever He wishes.

2.text: Every way of a man is right in his own eyes, / But Jehovah weighs the hearts.

3.text: To do righteousness and justice / Is more acceptable to Jehovah than sacrifice.

4.text: A high look and a proud heart -- / The lamp of the wicked -- is sin.

5.text: The plans of the diligent lead only to plentifulness, / But everyone who is hasty comes only to want.

6.text: The getting of treasures by a lying tongue / Is a fleeting vapor, a snare of death.

7.text: The violence of the wicked will sweep them away / Because they refuse to do justice.

8.text: The way of a guilty man is crooked; / But as for the pure, his work is right.

9.text: It is better to dwell in a corner of a housetop / Than in a house shared with a contentious woman.

10.text: The soul of the wicked man desires evil; / His neighbor finds no favor in his eyes.

11.text: When the scorner is punished, the simple man becomes wise; / And when the wise man is instructed, he receives knowledge.

12.text: The righteous One considers the house of the wicked man, / Overthrowing the wicked to their ruin.

13.text: Whoever closes his ear to the cry of the poor man / Also will cry and will not be heard.

14.text: A gift in secret pacifies anger; / And a present in the bosom, strong wrath.

15.text: It is joy to the righteous man to do justice, / But it is destruction to the workers of iniquity.

16.text: The man who wanders from the way of understanding / Will rest in the assembly of the dead.

17.text: He who loves pleasure will be a poor man; / He who loves wine and oil will not be rich.

18.text: The wicked man is a ransom for the righteous man, / And the treacherous man is in the place of the upright.

19.text: It is better to dwell in a desert land / Than with a contentious and vexing woman.

20.text: There is precious treasure and oil in the dwelling of the wise man, / But a foolish man swallows it up.

21.text: He who pursues righteousness and kindness / Finds life, righteousness, and honor.

22.text: A wise man scales the city of the mighty / And brings down the strength in which they trust.

23.text: Whoever guards his mouth and his tongue / Keeps his soul from troubles.

24.text: Proud, Haughty, Scorner are the names / Of him who works in the arrogance of pride.

25.text: The desire of the sluggard puts him to death, / For his hands refuse to work.

26.text: All day long one covets greedily, / But the righteous man gives and does not hold back.

27.text: The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination; / How much more when he brings it with evil intent!

28.text: A false witness will perish, / But the man who hears will speak so as to endure.

29.text: A wicked man hardens his face; / But as for the upright, he establishes his ways.

30.text: There is no wisdom nor understanding / Nor counsel that can avail against Jehovah.

31.text: The horse is prepared for the day of battle, / But victory belongs to Jehovah.

1.text: A good name is to be chosen rather than great riches, / And favor is better than silver and gold.

2.text: The rich and the poor have this in common: / Jehovah is the Maker of them all.

3.text: A prudent man sees evil and hides himself, / But the simple pass on and suffer punishment for it.

4.text: The reward of humility and the fear of Jehovah / Are riches and honor and life.

5.text: Thorns and snares are in the way of the perverse; / He who guards his soul will keep far from them.

6.text: Train up a child according to the way he should go; / Even when he is old, he will not depart from it.

7.text: The rich man rules over the poor, / And the borrower is servant to the lender.

8.text: He who sows injustice will reap iniquity, / And the rod of his wrath will fail.

9.text: He who is generous will be blessed, / For he gives some of his bread to the poor.

10.text: Cast out the scorner, and contention will go out; / Indeed, strife and dishonor will cease.

11.text: He who loves pureness of heart / And whose speech is gracious will have the king as his friend.

12.text: The eyes of Jehovah preserve knowledge, / But He overthrows the words of the treacherous man.

13.text: The sluggard says, There is a lion outside! / I will be slain in the streets!

14.text: The mouth of strange women is a deep pit; / He with whom Jehovah is indignant will fall in there.

15.text: Foolishness is bound up in the heart of a child; / But the rod of correction will drive it far from him.

16.text: He who oppresses the poor to multiply his gain, / And he who gives to the rich will only come to want.

17.text: Incline your ear, and hear the words of the wise, / And apply your heart to my knowledge;

18.text: For it is a pleasant thing if you keep them within you; / Let them be ready on your lips.

19.text: So that your trust may be in Jehovah, / I have made them known to you today, even to you.

20.text: Have I not written to you excellent things / Of counsels and knowledge,

21.text: To make you know the certainty of the words of truth, / That you may answer back words of truth to those who send you?

22.text: Do not rob the poor, because he is poor; / Nor oppress the afflicted in the gate;

23.text: For Jehovah will plead their cause, / And rob the life of those who rob them.

24.text: Make no friendship with a man who is given to anger, / And with a wrathful man do not go;

25.text: Lest you learn his ways / And get a snare for your soul.

26.text: Do not be one of those who give their hand as a pledge / Or one of those who are a surety for debts.

27.text: If you have nothing with which to pay, / Why should your bed be taken away from under you?

28.text: Do not remove the ancient boundary marker, / Which your fathers have set up.

29.text: Do you see a man skilled in his work? / He will stand before kings; / He will not stand before obscure men.

1.text: When you sit to eat with a ruler, / Consider carefully who is before you;

2.text: And put a knife to your throat / If you are a man of great appetite.

3.text: Do not desire his delicacies, / For they are deceitful food.

4.text: Do not weary yourself to become rich; / Cease from your consideration of it.

5.text: When you set your eyes upon it, it is gone; / For wealth certainly makes itself wings, / Like an eagle that flies toward heaven.

6.text: Do not eat the bread of one who is envious, / And do not desire his delicacies;

7.text: For as he thinks within himself, so he is. / He says to you, Eat and drink; / But his heart is not with you.

8.text: You will vomit up the morsel which you have eaten, / And waste your pleasant words.

9.text: Do not speak in the hearing of a fool, / For he will despise the wisdom of your words.

10.text: Do not remove the ancient boundary marker, / Or go into the fields of the fatherless;

11.text: For their Redeemer is strong; / He will plead their cause against you.

12.text: Apply your heart to instruction, / And your ears to words of knowledge.

13.text: Do not withhold correction from a child; / If you beat him with the rod, he will not die.

14.text: If you beat him with the rod, / You will deliver his soul from Sheol.

15.text: My son, if your heart is wise, / My own heart will also rejoice;

16.text: My inward parts will also exult, / When your lips speak right things.

17.text: Do not let your heart envy sinners, / But live in the fear of Jehovah all day long;

18.text: For surely there is a latter end, / And your hope will not be cut off.

19.text: Listen, my son, and be wise, / And direct your heart in the way.

20.text: Do not be among those who get drunk with wine, / Among gluttonous eaters of flesh;

21.text: For the drunkard and the glutton will come to poverty, / And drowsiness will clothe them with rags.

22.text: Listen to your father who begot you, / And do not despise your mother when she is old.

23.text: Buy truth, and do not sell it; / Buy wisdom and instruction and understanding.

24.text: The father of the righteous man will greatly exult, / And he who begets a wise child will rejoice in him.

25.text: Let your father and your mother rejoice, / And let her who bore you exult.

26.text: My son, give me your heart, / And let your eyes observe my ways.

27.text: For a harlot is a deep pit, / And an adulteress is a narrow well.

28.text: Indeed, she lies in wait as a robber, / And increases the number of the treacherous among men.

29.text: Who has woe? Who has sorrow? Who has contentions? / Who has complaining? Who has wounds without cause? Who has redness of eyes?

30.text: Those who linger late over wine, / Those who go to seek out mixed wines.

31.text: Do not look upon the wine when it is red, / When it sparkles in the cup, / When it goes down smoothly;

32.text: In the end it bites like a serpent, / And stings like an adder.

33.text: Your eyes will see strange things, / And your heart will utter perverse things;

34.text: And you will be like one who lies down while at sea, / Or like one who lies down at the top of a mast.

35.text: They struck me, you will say, but I was not hurt; / They beat me, but I did not feel it; / When will I awake? I will seek another drink.

1.text: Do not be envious of evil men, / Nor desire to be with them;

2.text: For their heart meditates violence, / And their lips talk of mischief.

3.text: Through wisdom a house is built, / And by understanding it is established,

4.text: And by knowledge the rooms are filled / With all precious and pleasant riches.

5.text: A wise man is strong, / And a man of knowledge increases power.

6.text: For by sound counsel you can wage your war, / And in the multitude of counselors there is victory.

7.text: Wisdom is too high for a fool; / He does not open his mouth in the gate.

8.text: He who devises to do evil, / Men will call him a mischief-maker.

9.text: The devising of folly is sin, / And the scorner is an abomination to men.

10.text: If you faint in the day of adversity, / Your strength is limited.

11.text: Deliver those who are being taken away to death, / And those who are staggering to be slain, oh, hold back!

12.text: If you say, Look, we did not know this -- / Does not He who weighs the hearts consider it? / And He who keeps your soul, does He not know it? / And will He not render to every man according to his work?

13.text: My son, eat honey, for it is good, / And the drippings from the honeycomb, which are sweet to your taste:

14.text: Know that wisdom is such for your soul; / If you find it, then there will be a latter end, / And your hope will not be cut off.

15.text: Do not lie in wait, O wicked man, against the dwelling of the righteous man; / Do not destroy his resting place;

16.text: For a righteous man falls seven times and rises up again, / But the wicked are overthrown by calamity.

17.text: Do not rejoice when your enemy falls, / And do not let your heart exult when he is overthrown;

18.text: Lest Jehovah see it, and it displease Him, / And He turn away His anger from him.

19.text: Do not be incensed because of evildoers; / Do not be envious of the wicked;

20.text: For there will be no future for the evil man; / The lamp of the wicked will be put out.

21.text: My son, fear Jehovah and the king, / And do not associate with those who are given to change;

22.text: For their calamity will rise suddenly, / And who knows the misfortune of both of them?

23.text: These also are sayings of the wise: / It is not good to have respect of persons in judgment.

24.text: He who says to the wicked man, You are righteous, / Peoples will curse him; nations will abhor him.

25.text: But those who rebuke the wicked man will have delight, / And a good blessing will come upon them.

26.text: He who gives an honest answer / Kisses the lips.

27.text: Prepare your work outside, / And make it ready for yourself in the field, / And afterward build your house.

28.text: Do not be a witness against your neighbor without cause, / And do not deceive with your lips.

29.text: Do not say, I will do to him as he has done to me; / I will render to the man according to his work.

30.text: I passed by the field of the sluggard, / And by the vineyard of the man lacking sense;

31.text: And there it was, all overgrown with thorns; / Its surface was covered with nettles, / And its stone wall was broken down.

32.text: When I looked, I considered it; / I saw it and received instruction:

33.text: A little sleep, a little slumber, / A little folding of the hands to rest,

34.text: And your poverty will come upon you like a robber, / And your want, like an armed man.

1.text: These also are proverbs of Solomon, which the men of Hezekiah the king of Judah copied.

2.text: It is the glory of God to conceal a matter, / But the glory of kings is to search a matter out.

3.text: As the heavens for height, and the earth for depth, / So the heart of kings is unsearchable.

4.text: Take away the dross from the silver, / And a vessel comes out for the smith;

5.text: Take away the wicked man from before the king, / And his throne will be established in righteousness.

6.text: Do not claim honor for yourself in the presence of the king, / And do not stand in the place of great men;

7.text: For it is better that it is said to you, Come up here, / Than that you should be put lower in the presence of the noble, / Whom your eyes have seen.

8.text: Do not go out hastily to strive; / Otherwise what will you do in the end, / When your neighbor puts you to shame?

9.text: Argue your case with your neighbor himself, / And do not reveal the secret of another;

10.text: Lest he who hears it revile you, / And the evil report of you does not go away.

11.text: A word fitly spoken / Is like apples of gold in settings of silver.

12.text: Like an earring of gold and an ornament of fine gold / Is a wise reprover to a listening ear.

13.text: Like the cold of snow in the time of harvest / Is a faithful messenger to those who send him, / For he refreshes the soul of his masters.

14.text: Like clouds and wind without rain / Is one who boasts of his gifts falsely.

15.text: By forbearance a ruler may be persuaded, / And a soft tongue can break the bone.

16.text: Have you found honey? Eat only what you need, / Lest you become filled up with it and vomit it.

17.text: Let your foot be seldom in your neighbor's house, / Otherwise he will become weary of you and hate you.

18.text: A man who bears false witness against his neighbor / Is like a club and a sword and a sharp arrow.

19.text: Confidence in a treacherous man in time of trouble / Is like a bad tooth and a foot out of joint.

20.text: He who sings songs to a troubled heart / Is like one who takes away a garment on a cold day, / Or like vinegar on soda.

21.text: If your enemy is hungry, give him bread to eat; / And if he is thirsty, give him water to drink;

22.text: For you will heap coals of fire upon his head, / And Jehovah will reward you.

23.text: The north wind brings forth rain; / And a backbiting tongue, an angry countenance.

24.text: It is better to dwell in a corner of the housetop / Than in a house shared with a contentious woman.

25.text: Like cold water to a thirsty soul, / So is good news from a far country.

26.text: Like a muddied fountain and a polluted spring / Is a righteous man who gives way before the wicked man.

27.text: It is not good to eat much honey, / Nor is it glory for men to search out their own glory.

28.text: Like a city that is broken down, without walls, / Is a man whose spirit is without restraint.

1.text: Like snow in summer and like rain in harvest, / So honor is not fitting for a fool.

2.text: Like the sparrow in its fluttering, like the swallow in its flying, / So a curse without cause does not alight.

3.text: A whip for the horse! A bridle for the donkey! / And a rod for the back of fools!

4.text: Do not answer a fool according to his folly, / Lest you also be like him.

5.text: Answer a fool according to his folly, / Lest he be wise in his own eyes.

6.text: He who sends a message by the hand of a fool / Cuts off his own feet and drinks violence.

7.text: Like the legs of the lame which hang down, / So is a proverb in the mouth of fools.

8.text: Like one who binds a stone in a sling, / So is he who gives honor to a fool.

9.text: Like a thorn that goes up into the hand of a drunkard, / So is a proverb in the mouth of fools.

10.text: Like an archer who wounds everyone, / So is he who hires a fool or who hires those who pass by.

11.text: Like a dog that returns to its vomit / Is a fool who repeats his folly.

12.text: Do you see a man who is wise in his own eyes? / There is more hope for a fool than for him.

13.text: The sluggard says, There is a roaring lion on the way; / A lion is in the streets!

14.text: As the door turns upon its hinges, / So does the sluggard upon his bed.

15.text: The sluggard buries his hand in the dish; / He gets weary by bringing it to his mouth again.

16.text: The sluggard is wiser in his own eyes / Than seven men who can answer discreetly.

17.text: He who passes by and meddles with strife that does not belong to him, / Is like one who takes a dog by the ears.

18.text: Like a madman who shoots firebrands, arrows, and death,

19.text: So is the man who deceives his neighbor, / And says, Was I not joking?

20.text: For lack of wood the fire goes out, / And where there is no whisperer, contention quiets down.

21.text: As charcoal to hot embers and wood to fire, / So is a contentious man to kindle strife.

22.text: The words of a whisperer are like dainty morsels, / And they go down into the innermost parts of one's being.

23.text: Burning lips and a wicked heart / Are like an earthen vessel overlaid with silver dross.

24.text: He who hates disguises it with his lips, / But he lays up deceit within him;

25.text: When he speaks graciously, do not believe him; / For there are seven abominations in his heart;

26.text: Though his hatred covers itself with guile, / His wickedness will be revealed before the assembly.

27.text: Whoever digs a pit will fall into it, / And he who rolls a stone, it will come back on him.

28.text: A lying tongue hates those it crushes, / And a flattering mouth works ruin.

1.text: Do not boast about tomorrow, / For you do not know what a day may bring forth.

2.text: Let another praise you, and not your own mouth; / A foreigner, and not your own lips.

3.text: A stone is heavy, and the sand weighty, / But a fool's vexation is heavier than both of them.

4.text: Wrath is cruel, and anger is overwhelming, / But who can stand before jealousy?

5.text: Open rebuke is better / Than love that is hidden.

6.text: Faithful are the wounds of a friend, / But the kisses of an enemy are profuse.

7.text: The full soul loathes a honeycomb, / But to the hungry soul every bitter thing is sweet.

8.text: Like a bird that wanders from her nest, / So is a man who wanders from his place.

9.text: Oil and perfume rejoice the heart; / So a man's counsel is sweet to his friend.

10.text: Do not forsake your own friend or your father's friend / To go to your brother's house in the day of your calamity: / Better is a neighbor who is near than a brother far away.

11.text: My son, be wise, and make my heart glad, / That I may answer him who reproaches me.

12.text: A prudent man sees evil and hides himself; / But the simple pass on and suffer punishment for it.

13.text: Take the garment of him who is surety for a stranger, / And hold one in pledge who is surety for a foreign woman.

14.text: He who blesses his friend with a loud voice, / Arousing him early in the morning, / It will be reckoned as a curse to him.

15.text: A continual dripping on a very rainy day / And a contentious woman are alike;

16.text: He who would restrain her restrains the wind, / And grasps oil with his right hand.

17.text: Iron sharpens iron; / So a man sharpens the countenance of his friend.

18.text: Whoever tends a fig tree will eat its fruit, / And he who takes care of his master will be honored.

19.text: As in water face reflects face, / So the heart of man reflects man.

20.text: Sheol and Abaddon are never satisfied, / And the eyes of man are never satisfied.

21.text: The refining pot is for silver and the furnace for gold, / And a man is tried by the praise given him.

22.text: Though you pound a fool in a mortar with a pestle along with crushed grain, / His folly will not depart from him.

23.text: Know well the condition of your flocks, / And pay attention to your herds --

24.text: For riches are not forever, / Nor does a crown endure from generation to generation --

25.text: Then when the grass has disappeared, and the tender grass is seen, / And the herbs of the mountains have been gathered in,

26.text: The lambs will be for your clothing, / And the goats will bring the price of a field;

27.text: And there will be goats' milk enough for your food, / For the food of your household, / And for the sustenance for your maidens.

1.text: The wicked flee when no man pursues, / But the righteous are as bold as a lion.

2.text: When a land revolts, it has many rulers; / But by him who has understanding and knowledge it endures.

3.text: A destitute man who oppresses the poor / Is like a driving rain which leaves no food.

4.text: Those who forsake the law praise the wicked, / But those who keep the law contend with them.

5.text: Evil men do not understand justice, / But those who seek Jehovah understand all things.

6.text: Better is a poor man who walks in his integrity / Than he who is perverse in his ways though he is rich.

7.text: Whoever keeps the law is an understanding son, / But he who is a companion of gluttons shames his father.

8.text: He who increases his substance by interest and usury / Gathers it for him who is gracious to the poor.

9.text: He who turns away his ear from hearing the law, / Even his prayer is an abomination.

10.text: Whoever causes the upright to go astray in an evil way / Will himself fall into his own pit, / But the perfect will inherit good.

11.text: The rich man is wise in his own conceit, / But the poor man who has understanding searches him out.

12.text: When the righteous triumph, there is great glory; / But when the wicked rise, men hide themselves.

13.text: He who covers his transgressions will not prosper, / But whoever confesses and forsakes them will obtain mercy.

14.text: Blessed is the man who always fears, / But he who hardens his heart will fall into calamity.

15.text: Like a roaring lion and a roving bear / Is a wicked ruler over a poor people.

16.text: The ruler who lacks understanding is also a great oppressor, / But he who hates unjust gain will prolong his days.

17.text: A man who is burdened with a person's blood / Will be a fugitive until death; / Let no man support him.

18.text: Whoever walks uprightly will be delivered, / But he who is perverse in his ways will fall all at once.

19.text: He who tills his land will have plenty of bread, / But he who pursues worthless things will have plenty of poverty.
