20.text: A faithful man will abound with blessings, / But he who makes haste to be rich will not go unpunished.

21.text: To have respect of persons is not good, / Because for a piece of bread a man will transgress.

22.text: A man who is envious hastens after wealth, / And does not know that want will come upon him.

23.text: He who rebukes a man will afterward find more favor / Than he who flatters with the tongue.

24.text: Whoever robs his father or his mother and says, / It is no transgression, / Is the companion of a man who destroys.

25.text: A greedy person stirs up contention, / But he who trusts in Jehovah will prosper.

26.text: He who trusts in his own heart is a fool, / But he who walks wisely will be delivered.

27.text: He who gives to the poor man will not lack, / But he who shuts his eyes will have many curses.

28.text: When the wicked rise, men hide themselves; / But when they perish, the righteous increase.

1.text: He who hardens his neck after being often reproved / Will suddenly be broken beyond remedy.

2.text: When the righteous increase, the people rejoice; / But when a wicked man rules, the people groan.

3.text: Whoever loves wisdom makes his father glad, / But he who keeps company with harlots wastes his substance.

4.text: The king by justice establishes the land, / But a man who takes bribes overthrows it.

5.text: A man who flatters his neighbor / Spreads a net for his steps.

6.text: In the transgression of an evil man there is a snare, / But the righteous man sings and rejoices.

7.text: The righteous man knows the rights of the poor; / The wicked man has no understanding of such knowledge.

8.text: Scorners set a city aflame, / But wise men turn away wrath.

9.text: If a wise man has a controversy with a foolish man, / The fool is either angry or laughs, and there is no rest.

10.text: The bloodthirsty hate one who is perfect, / And they seek the life of the upright.

11.text: A fool utters all his anger, / But a wise man holds it back.

12.text: If a ruler pays attention to a false word, / All his servants are wicked.

13.text: The poor man and the oppressor have this in common: / Jehovah gives light to the eyes of them both.

14.text: If a king judges the poor in truth, / His throne will be established forever.

15.text: The rod and reproof give wisdom, / But a child left to himself brings shame to his mother.

16.text: When the wicked increase, transgression increases; / But the righteous will see their fall.

17.text: Correct your son, and he will give you rest; / He will also give delight to your soul.

18.text: Where there is no vision, the people cast off restraint; / But happy is he who keeps the law.

19.text: A servant will not be corrected by words alone; / For though he understands, there will be no response.

20.text: Do you see a man who is hasty in his words? / There is more hope for a fool than for him.

21.text: He who delicately brings up his servant from a child / Will have him as a son in the end.

22.text: An angry man stirs up contention, / And a furious man abounds in transgression.

23.text: A man's pride will bring him low, / But he who is of a lowly spirit will obtain honor.

24.text: Whoever is partner with a thief hates his own soul; / He hears the adjuration and utters nothing.

25.text: The fear of man brings a snare, / But whoever puts his trust in Jehovah will be exalted.

26.text: Many seek the ruler's favor, / But justice for man comes from Jehovah.

27.text: An unjust man is an abomination to the righteous, / And he who is upright in the way is an abomination to the wicked man.

1.text: The words of Agur the son of Jakeh. The oracle. / The man declares to Ithiel, to Ithiel and Ucal:

2.text: Surely I am more stupid than any man, / And do not have a man's understanding;

3.text: And I have not learned wisdom, / Nor do I have the knowledge of the Holy One.

4.text: Who has ascended into heaven and descended? / Who has gathered the wind in His fists? / Who has wrapped up the waters in His garment? / Who has established all the ends of the earth? / What is His name, and what is His Son's name, if you know?

5.text: Every word of God is tried; / He is a shield to those who take refuge in Him.

6.text: Do not add to His words, / Lest He reprove you and you be found a liar.

7.text: Two things I have asked of You; / Do not refuse me before I die:

8.text: Remove far from me falsehood and lies. / Give me neither poverty nor riches; / Feed me with the food that is my portion,

9.text: Lest I become full and deny You and say, Who is Jehovah? / Or lest I become poor and steal and profane the name of my God.

10.text: Do not slander a servant to his master, / Lest he curse you, and you be held guilty.

11.text: There is a generation that curse their father, / And do not bless their mother.

12.text: There is a generation that are pure in their own eyes, / And yet are not washed from their filthiness.

13.text: There is a generation -- oh how lofty are their eyes, / And their eyelids are raised arrogantly.

14.text: There is a generation whose teeth are like swords, / And their jaw teeth like knives, / To devour the afflicted from off the earth, / And the needy from among men.

15.text: The leech has two daughters, crying, Give, give. / There are three things that are never satisfied, / Indeed, four that do not say, Enough:

16.text: Sheol and the barren womb, / The earth that is not satisfied with water, / And the fire that does not say, Enough.

17.text: The eye that mocks his father / And despises to obey his mother, / The ravens of the valley will pick it out, / And the young eagles will eat it.

18.text: There are three things which are too wonderful for me, / Indeed four which I do not know:

19.text: The way of an eagle in the sky, / The way of a serpent upon a rock, / The way of a ship in the midst of the sea, / And the way of a man with a maiden.

20.text: This is the way of an adulterous woman: / She eats and wipes her mouth / And says, I have done no wickedness.

21.text: Under three things the earth quakes, / And under four, it cannot bear up:

22.text: Under a servant when he is king, / And a fool when he is filled with food;

23.text: Under a hated woman when she gets married, / And a servant girl who is heir to her mistress.

24.text: Four things are small on the earth, / But they are exceedingly wise:

25.text: The ants are a clan without strength, / Yet they prepare their food in the summer;

26.text: The rock badgers are a clan without might, / Yet they make their houses in the rocks;

27.text: The swarming locusts have no king, / Yet all of them go out in ranks;

28.text: The lizard can be grasped with the hands, / Yet she is in kings' palaces.

29.text: There are three things which are stately in their step, / Indeed four which are stately in walking:

30.text: The lion, which is mightiest among beasts, / And does not turn back before any;

31.text: The strutting cock girded in the loins, or a male goat, / And a king who has a band of soldiers with him.

32.text: If you have been foolish in exalting yourself, / Or if you have thought an evil scheme, / Put your hand upon your mouth.

33.text: For the churning of milk produces butter, / And the wringing of the nose brings forth blood, / So the pressing of wrath brings forth strife.

1.text: The words of King Lemuel. The oracle which his mother taught him.

2.text: What, my son? and what, O son of my womb? / And what, O son of my vows?

3.text: Do not give your strength to women, / Nor your ways to that which destroys kings.

4.text: It is not for kings, O Lemuel, it is not for kings to drink wine; / Nor for princes to say, Where is strong drink?

5.text: Lest they drink and forget what is decreed, / And pervert the rights of all the afflicted.

6.text: Give strong drink rather to one who is perishing, / And wine to the bitter in soul;

7.text: Let him drink and forget his poverty, / And remember his misery no more.

8.text: Open your mouth for the dumb, / And for the rights of all those who are passing away.

9.text: Open your mouth; judge righteously, / And minister justice to the poor and needy.

10.text: Who can find a worthy woman? / For her price is far above corals.

11.text: The heart of her husband trusts in her, / And he will have no lack of gain.

12.text: She does him good and not evil / All the days of her life.

13.text: She seeks wool and flax, / And delights to work with her hands.

14.text: She is like the merchant ships; / She brings her food from afar.

15.text: She rises also while it is still night / And gives food to her household, / And their task to her serving girls.

16.text: She considers a field and buys it; / With the fruit of her hands she plants a vineyard.

17.text: She girds her loins with strength / And makes strong her arms.

18.text: She samples her merchandise to be sure it is good; / Her lamp does not go out by night.

19.text: She lays her hands to the distaff, / And her hands hold on to the spindle.

20.text: She stretches out her hand to the afflicted, / And she reaches out her hands to the needy.

21.text: She does not fear for her household when it snows, / For all her household are clothed with scarlet.

22.text: She makes coverings for herself; / Her clothing is fine linen and purple.

23.text: Her husband is known in the gates, / When he sits among the elders of the land.

24.text: She makes linen garments and sells them / And delivers girdles to the merchant.

25.text: Strength and dignity are her clothing, / And she happily looks forward to the time to come.

26.text: She opens her mouth with wisdom, / And the law of kindness is on her tongue.

27.text: She watches closely over the ways of her household / And does not eat the bread of idleness.

28.text: Her children rise up and call her blessed; / Her husband also, and he praises her, saying:

29.text: Many daughters have done worthily, / But you surpass them all.

30.text: Grace is deceitful, and beauty is vain; / But a woman who fears Jehovah, she will be praised.

31.text: Give her of the fruit of her hands, / And let her works praise her in the gates.
